encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Alphonso Seberto Pedro Curio Alinda old pilgrim Juletta Roderigo Porter 1.Beggar 2.Beggar 3.Beggar 4.Beggar Lopez Jaques Governour Verdugo 1 Outlaw 2 Outlaw 3 Outlaw 4 Outlaw Gentleman 1 Keeper combined speech 1 Servant 2 Servant 2 Keeper A mad Englishman She Fool Master 2 Gentleman A mad Scholar 1 Peasant 2 Peasant 3 Peasant 4 Peasant A mad Parson A mad Welshman 1 Citizen 2 Citizen 3 Citizen

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.l: Signor Alphonso, ye are too rugged to her,
Believe too full of harshness.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes, it seems so.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A father of so sweet a child, so happy,
(Fie Sir) so excellent in all endowments,
In blessedness of beauty, such a mirror.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: She is a fool, away.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Can ye be angry?
Can any wind blow rough, upon a blossom
So fair, and tender? Can a Fathers nature,
A noble Fathers too?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: All this is but prating:
Let her be ruled; let her observe my humour,
With my eyes let her see; with my ears listen;
I am her Father: I begot her,bred her,
And I will make her.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: No doubt ye may compel her,
But what a mischievous, unhappy fortune
May wait upon this will of yours, as commonly
Such forcings ever end in hates, and ruins.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Is it not a man I wish her to? a strong man?
What can she have? what could she have? a Gentleman?
A young man? and an able man? a rich man?
A handsome man? a valiant man? do you mark me?
None of your pieced companions, your pined Gallants,
That fly to fitters, with every flaw of weather:
None of your impt bravadoes: what can she ask more?
Is not a mettled man fit for a woman?
A strong chinned man? I will not be fooled, nor flirted.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I grant ye is all these Rodorgio
And a brave Gentleman: must it therefore follow
Upon necessity she must dote upon him?
Will ye allow no liberty in choosing?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Alas she is tender yet.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Enough enough, enough Sir:
She is malleable; she will endure the hammer,
And why not that strong workman that strikes deepest?
Let me know that? she is fifteen, with the vantage,
And if she be not ready now for manage

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You know he is a banished man: an out Law;
And how he lives: his nature rough, and bloody
By customary rapines: now,her sweet humour
That is as easy as a calm, and peaceful,
All her affections, like the dews on Roses,
Fair as the flowers themselves: as sweet,and gentle:
How would you have these meet?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A bed, a bed sir:
Let her be the fairest Rose, and the sweetest,
Yet I know this fair rose must have her prickles:
I grant ye is an outlaw , Rodorigo
An easy composition calls him in again,
He is a valiant man, and he is a rich man,
And loves the fool: a little rough by custom:
She will like him ten times better. She will do at upon him,
If ere they come to grappling, run mad for him;
But there is another in the wind, some castrell
That hovers over her,and dares her daily,
Some flickering slave.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I dare not think so poorly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Something there is, and must be: but I shall sent it
And hunt it narrowly.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I never saw her yet
Make offer at the least glance of affection,
But still so modest, wise.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: They are wise to gull us,
There was a fellow, old son, Ferandos
I must confess handsome, but my enemy,
And the whole family, I hate young Pedro
That fellow I have seen her gaze upon,
And turn, and gaze again, and make such offers
As if she would shoot her eyes like meteors at him:
But that cause stands removed.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: You need not doubt him,
For long since as it was thought on a grieved conscience,
He left his father, and his friends: more pity:
For truth reports he was a noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let him be what he will: he was a beggar,
And there I will leave him.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The more the Court must answer;
But certainly I think, though she might favour him,
And love his goodness, as he was an honest man:
She never with loose eyes stuck on his person.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She is so full of conscience too, and charity,
And outward holiness, she will undo me:
Relieves more beggars, than an hospital;

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And all poor rogues, that can but say their prayers,
And tune their pipes to Lamentations,
She thinks she is bound to dance too : good morrow to you,
And that is as ye deserve too: you know my mind,
And study to observe it: do it cheerfully,
And readily, and home.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I shall obey ye.
But noble sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come, come, away with your flatteries,
And your fine phrases,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Pray ye be gentle to her:

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I know them; and know your feats: if you will find me
Noble and loving, seek me in your duty,
You know I am too indulgent.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Alas poor Lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: To your devotions: I take no good thing from you
Come Gentlemen; leave pitying, and moaning of her,
And praising of her virtues: and her whim whams,
It makes her proud, and sturdy:

sp.speaker: Seb.Cur.
sp.l: Good hours wait on ye.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I thank ye Gentlemen: I want such comforts:
I would thank you too father: but your cruelty
Hath almost made me senseless of my duty,
Yet still I must know: would I had known nothing;
What Poor attend my charity today , wench?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Of all sort, Madam; your open handed bounty
Makes them flock every hour: some worth your pity,
But others that have made a trade of begging.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Wench, if they ask it truly, must give it: I
It takes away the holy use of charity
To examine wants.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I would you would be merry:
A cheerful giving hand, as think, Madam, I
Requires a heart as cheerful.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Alas Iuletta
What is there to be merry at? what joy now,
Unless we fool our own afflictions,
And make them show ridiculous?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sure Madam,
You could not seem thus serious, if you were married,
Thus sad, and full of thoughts.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Married? to whom, wench?
Thou thinkst if there be a young handsome fellow
As those are plentiful, our cares are quenched then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Madam, think a lusty handsome fellow I
If he be kind, and loving, and a right one,
Is even as good a pill, to purge this melancholy,
As ever gave, am sure more natural: I
And merrier for the heart, than Wine and Saffron:
Madam, wanton youth is such a Cataplasm.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Who has been thy tutor wench?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Even my own thoughts, Lady:
For though be bard the liberty of talking,
Yet I can think unhappily, and as near the mark, Madam,
In Faith, marry, and be merry.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Who will have me?
Who will be troubled with a tettish Girl?
It may be proud, and to that vice expenseful?
Who can assure himself, I shall live honest?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Let every man take his fortune:

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And on my conscience
If once I grow to breeding, a whole Kingdom
Will not contain my stock.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The more the merrier:
It is brave to be a mother of new Nations.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Why, I should bury a hundred husbands.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It is no matter:
As long as ye leave sufficient men to stock ye.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Is this thy mirth? are these the joys of marriage?
Away light headed fool; are these contentments?
If I could find a man.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You may a thousand.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Mere men I know I may: and there a woman
Has liberty, at least she will venture for it,
To be a monster and become the time too;
But to enjoy a man, from whose example
(As from a compass) we may steer our fortunes,
Our actions, and our age; and safe arrive at
A memory that shall become our ashes,
Such things are few, and far to seek; to find one
That can but rightly manage the willed beast, woman,
And sweetly govern with her. But no more of this, wench,
It is not for thy discourse: Let us in,and see
What poor afflicted wait our charity.

body.stage: Enter a Porter,4. Beggers,Pedro,and a Pilgrime.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Stand off, and keep your Ranks: twenty foot further:
There louse yourselves with reason, and ; discretion.
The Sun shines warm: the farther still the better,
Your beasts will bolt anon, and then it is dangerous.

sp.speaker: 1.Beg.
sp.l: Heaven bless our Mistress.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Does the crack go that way?
It will be of the other side anon.
Pray ye friend.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Your friend? and why your friend? why, goodman turncoat
What dost thou see within me, or without me,
Or what itch dost thou know upon me, tell me,
That I should be thy friend? what do I look like
Any of thy acquaintance hung in Gibbets?
Hast thou any Friends, Kindred,or Alliance,
Or any higher ambition, than an alms basket?

sp.speaker: 2.Beg.
sp.l: I would be your worships friend.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: So ye shall Sirrah,
When I quarter the same louse with ye.
It is twelve o'clock.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is ever so with thee, when thou hast done scratching,
For that provokes thy stomach to ring noon;
O the infinite Seas of porridge thou hast swallowed
And yet thou lookest as if they had been but Glisters;
Thou feedest abundance; thou hadst need of sustenance;
Alms do you call it to relieve these Rascals?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Nothing but a general rot of sheep can satisfy them .

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Did not I tell you, how she would undo me?
What Marts of Rogues, and Beggars?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It is charity
Methinks, you are bound to love her for

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes, I warrant ye,
If men could sale to heaven in porridge pots,
With masts of Beef, and Mutton, what a voyage should I make?
What are all these?
Poor people, if it like your worship.
Wretched poor people.
Very hungry people.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And very Lousy.
Yes forsooth, so,so.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I will undertake five hundred head about them,
And that is no needy Grazier.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Strangers that come to wonder at your charity,
Yet people poor enough to beg a blessing.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Use them with favour, sir, their shows are reverent,
It seems ye are holy Pilgrims

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Ye guess right sir,
And bound far off, to offer our devotions.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What make ye this way? we keep no Relics here,
Nor holy Shrines.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: The holiest we ere heard of;
Ye keep a living monument of goodness,
A Daughter of that pious excellence,
The very Shrines of Saints sink at her virtues,
And swear they cannot hold pace with her pities,
We come to see this Lady: not with profane eyes,
Nor wanton bloods, to do at upon her beauties,
But through our tedious ways to beg her blessings.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This is a new way of begging, and a neat one,
And this cries money for reward: good store too;
These commendations beg not with bag, and bottle;
Well, well, the sainting of this woman (Gentlemen)
I know what it must come to : these women saints
Are plaguey heavy saints: they outweigh a he saint
Three thousand thick; I know: I feel.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ye are more afraid than hurt sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Have you your commendations ready too?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A handsome well built person.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What Country craver are you? nothing but motion?
A puppet Pilgrim?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: He is a stranger sir;
This four days I have travelled in his company,
But little of his business, or his Language
As yet, I have understood.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Both young, and handsome,
Only the Sun has been too saucy with him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Would ye have money sir, or meat? what kind of blessing
Does your devotion look for? Still more ducking?
Be there any saints, that understand by signs only?
More motion yet? this is the prettiest Pilgrim,
The pink of pilgrims: I will be for ye sir;
Do ye discourse with signs? ye are heartily well come:
A poor viaticum; very good gold sir;
But holy men affect a better treasure.
I kept it for your goodness, but nevertheless
Since it can prove but burdensome to your holiness,
And you affect light prayer, fit for carriage,
I will put this up again .

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Ye are too unreverent.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ye talk too broad; must I give way, and wealth too
To every toy,that carries a grave seeming?
Must my good angels wait on him? if the proud hilding
Would yield but to my will, and know her duty
I knew what I would suffer.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good sir, be patient,
The wrongs ye do these men, may light on you,
Too heavy too: and then you will wish you had said less;
A comely and sweet usage becomes strangers.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: We shall have half the Kingdom strangers shortly,
And this fond prodigality be suffered;
But I must be an ass, see them relieved, sirrah;
If I were young again, I would sooner get bear whelps,
And safer too, than any of these She saints,
But I will break her,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Such a face for certain.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Methinks I have seen it too: but we are cozened;
But fair befall thee Pilgrim, thou lookest lovely.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Will ye troop up, ye porridge Regiment?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Captain Poors quarter will ye move?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Ye dull Knave,
Are not these wretches served yet?

sp.speaker: 1.Beg.
sp.l: Bless my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Do you make sport sir, with their miseries?
Ye drowsy rogue.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: They are too high fed, Madam,
Their stomachs are asleep yet.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Serve them plentifully,
Or I will serve you out next: even out of doors, sirrah;
And serve them quickly too.

sp.speaker: 1.Beg.
sp.l: Heaven bless the Lady.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Bless the good end I mean it for.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I would I knew it:
If it be for any man's sake, I will cry amen too,
Well Madam, ye have even as pretty a port of pensioners.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Vain glory would seek more, and handsomer.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: But I appeal to virtue what my end is;

sp.speaker: Beggers
sp.l: What men are these?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It seems they are holy Pilgrims:
That handsome youth should suffer such a penance,
Would I were even the saint they make their vows too,
How easily I would grant.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Heavens grace in wheel ye:
And all good thoughts, and prayers dwell about ye,
Abundance be your friend; and holy charity
Be ever at your hand to crown ye glorious.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I thank ye sir; peace guide your travels too,
And what you wish for most, end all your troubles;
Remember me by this: and in your prayers
When your strong heart melts, mediate my poor fortunes.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: All my devotions wait upon your service.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Are ye of this Country, sir?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Yes, worthiest Lady,
But far off bred: my fortunes farther from me.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Gentle, I dare believe.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I have lived freer.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I am no inquisitor, that were too curious:
What ever vow, or penance pulls ye on sir;
Conscience, or love, or stubborn disobedience,
The saint ye kneel too, hear, and ease your travels.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Yours near begin: and thus I seal my prayers.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: How constantly this man looks? how he sighs?
Some great affliction hatches his devotions,
Right holy sir: how young, and sweet he suffers?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would I might suffer with him.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: He turns from us:
Alas he weeps too: something presses him
He would reveal, but dare not; sir, be comforted,
Ye come for that:and take it: if it be want, sir,
To me ye appear so worthy of relieving,
I am your steward: speak, and take:he is dumb still:
Now as I have a faith this man so stirs me,
His modesty makes me afraid I have trespassed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would he would stir me too: I like his shape well.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: May be he would speak alone: go off Iuletta
Afflicted hearts fear their own motions,
Be not far off.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would I were nearer to him,
A young smug handsome holiness has no fellow.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Why do you grieve? do you find your penance sharp?
O rare the vows ye have made, too mighty for ye?
Does not the world allure ye to look back
And sorrow for the sweet time ye have lost?
Ye are young, and fair; be not deluded, sir;
A manly made up heart contemns these shadows,
And yours appears no less: griefs for your fears,
For hours ill spent, for wrongs done rash, and rudely,
For foul contempts for faiths ill violated,
Become fears well: I dare not task your Goodness:
And then a sorrow shows in his true glory
When the whole heart is excellently sorry.
I pray ye be comforted.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I am, dear Lady,
And such a comfort ye have cast upon me,
That though I struggle with mine own calamities
Too mighty, and too many for my manage,
And though,like angry waves, they curled upon me
Contending proudly who should first devour me,
Yet I would stem their danger.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: He speaks nobly:
What do ye want?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: All that can make me happy:
I want myself.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Yourself ? who robbed ye Pilgrim?
Why does he look so constantly upon me?
I want myself: indeed, you holy wanderers
Are said to seek much: but to seek yourselves .

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I seek myself ; and am but myselfs shadow:
Have lost myself ; and now am not so noble.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I seek myself : something I yet remember
That bears that Motto; it is not he: he is younger,
And far more tender: for that self sake (Pilgrim)
Be who it will, take this.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Your hand I dare take,
That be far from me, Lady, thus I kiss it,
And thus I bless it too; be constant fair still:
Be good, and live to be a great example.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: One word more (Pilgrim) has amazed me strangely,
Be constant fair still: it is the posy here:
And here without, Be good: he wept to see me

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Take this Key, and fetch me
The Marygold Jewel that lies in my little Cabinet:
I think it is that: what eyes had I, to miss him?
O me, what thoughts? he had no beard then, and
As I remember well, he was more ruddy.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: If this be he, he has a manly face yet
A goodly shape.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Here Madam?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Let me see it:
It is so, too true: It must be he, or nothing,
He spake the words just as they stand engraved here:
I seek myself , and am but my selves shadow:
Alas poor man: didst thou not meet him, Iuletta
The Pilgrim wench?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He went by long ago, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I forgot to give him something.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It was ill done Lady:
For,on my troth, he is the handsomest man
I saw this many a day: would he had all my wealth,
And me to boot: what ails she to grow sullen?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Come, I forgot: but I will recompense it.

body.stage: Enter Alphonso, Curio, Seberto, Iuletta, Porter, and servants.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Can she slip through a cat hole? tell me that: resolve me;
Can she fly in the air? is she a thing invisible?
Gone, and none know it?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ye amaze your servants.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Some pelting rogue has watched her hour of itching,
And clawed her; clawed her: do you mark me, clawed her;
Some that I foster up.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: They are all here, sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let them be where they will, they are arrant rascals,
And by this hand I will hang them all.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Deal calmly:
You will not give them time to answer ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I will choke them : famish them: what say you wagtail?
You knew her mind: you were of council with her,
Tell me: and tell me true.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Ask with discretion.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Discretion? hang discretion, hang ye all:
Let me know where she is.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would you know of me sir?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Of thee sir: I, of thee sir: what art thou sir?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Her woman sir, if it like your worship, sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Her band, her fiddle stick.
Her Lady fairy, to oil the doors of nights,
That they may open with discretion,
Her Gin, her Nut crack,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It is very well sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thou liest; it is damnable ill, it is most abominable:
Will ye confess (Thing)

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Say I were guilty, sir?
I would be hanged before I would confess:
Is this a World to confess in?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Deal directly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, if my matter lie direct before me:
But when I am forced, and ferreted.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Tell me the truth,
And as I live, I will give thee a new petticoat.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If you would give me ten, I would not tell ye,
Truths bear a greater price, than you are aware of.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Deal modestly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do not pluck my cloths up.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What say you sirra? you? or you? are ye dumb all?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I saw her last night,if it shall like your worship
When I served in her Livery.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What is that, sirra?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Her Chamber pot, if it please ye.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A new Livery.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Where lay she? who lay with her?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: In truth not I sir:
I lay with my fellow Fredrick in the flea chamber
If it like your worship, we are almost worried.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I left her by herself ,in her own closet,
And there I thought she had slept.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why lay you from her?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It was her will I should: she is my Mistress,
And my part is obedience.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Were all the doors locked?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: All mine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And mine: she could not get out those ways
Unless she leapt the walls: and those are higher
Than any woman's courage dare aspire at.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come, you must know.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Conceal it not, but deal plain.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If I did know, and her trust lay upon me,
Not all your angers, nor your flatteries
Should make me speak, but having no more interest
Than I may well deliver to the air,
I will tell ye what I know: and tell it liberally,
I think she is gone, because we cannot find her;
I think she is weary of your tyranny,
And therefore gone: maybe she is in love:
May be in love, where you show no great liking,
And therefore gone: May be, some point of conscience,
Or vowed devotion.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: These are nothing, minion;
You that can aim at these, must know the truth too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Any more truth than this if I know hang me,
Or where to search for it, if I make a lie
To gain your love, and envy my best Mistress,
Pin me against a wall, with my heels upwards.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That is all my poor petition:
For if your house were gold, and she not in it,
Sir, I should count it but a cage to whistle in.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Whore, if she be above ground, I will have her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I would live in a cole pit, then, were I your daughter.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Certain she does not know Sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Hang her, hang her:
She knows too much: search all the house; all corners,
And where it is possible she may go out,

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: If I do find your tricks.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Reward me for them .
Or if I had such tricks, you could discover
So weak, and slightly woven, you might look through,
All the young Girls should hoot me out of the Parish.
You are my Master, but ye own an anger
Becomes a School boy, that hath lost his Apples;
Will ye force things into our knowledges?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come hither thou didst love me. Juletta

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And do still:
You are my Ladies father, and I reverence ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thou wouldst have pleased my humour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Any good way,
That carried not suspicion in it: or flattery,
Or fail of trust.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come, come, thou wouldst have.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Stay sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And thou hast felt my bounty for it, and shalt do.
Dost thou want Clothes or Money?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Both.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Shalt have both.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But not this way: I had rather be an Adamite
And bring Fig leaves into fashion again.
If you were young sir,
Handsome, and fitted to a woman's appetite;
And I a giddy headed girl, that cared for nothing,
Much might be done; then you might fumble with me,
And think to grope out matters of some moment,
Which now you will put too short for:
For what you have seen hitherto,
And know by me, has been but honest service,
Which I dare pin in the market place to answer;
And let the world, the flesh and devil examine it,
And come you in too, I dare stand your strictest.
And so much good may do you, with your dreams of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This is most monstrous.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sure she does not know sir:
She durst not be so confident and guilty.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How now; what news? what hopes and steps discovered?
Speak anything that is good, that tends to the matter ;
Do you stand staring still?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: We are no Gods sir,
To say she is here, or there: and what she is doing;
But we have searched.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I am sure she is not in the Cellar;
For look you sir, if she had been in the Cellar

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am sure thou hast been there.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: As I carried the matter,
For I searched every piece of Wine; yes sure sir,
And every little Teresse that could but testify:
And I drew hard to bolt her out.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Away with him;
Fling him in the Haymow, let him lie a mellowing;
He stinks of Muscatel like an English Christmas:
Are these your cares? your services?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Pray ye hear sir,
We have found where she went out; her very footing.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Where where? go on.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Observe then with more staidness.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Searching the garden: at the little Postern
That opens to the Park, we first discovered it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A little foot?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: It must be hers, or none sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How far beyond that?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: To the Park it leads us,
But there the ground being hard, we could not mark it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: She always kept that Key: I was a coxcomb,
A fool, an ass,to give a girl that liberty:
Saddle my Horses, rogues, ye drunken varlets:
Your precious diligence lies in Pint pots,
Your brains in Butts, my horses, ye pin buttocks.
You will bear me company?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We dare not leave ye,
Unless we found a quieter soul within ye.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: If we may do the Lady any service,
Sweet, gentle soul.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I say again, my horses:
Are ye so hot? have ye your private pilgrimages?
Must ye be Jumping Jone? I will wander with ye:
I will jump ye, and I will joggle ye: my horses;
And keep me this young Lirry poop within doors,
I will discover, dame.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It is fit you should sir,
If ye knew what: Well Love, if thou beest with her,
Or what power else that arms her resolution,
Conduct her fair, and keep her from this mad man,
Direct her to her wishes: dwell about her
That no dishonourable end over take her,
Danger, or want: and let me try my fortune.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You know the place we meet in?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We shall hit it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And as ye are honest Gentlemen, endeavour.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: We will search the best we can: if she light in our hands.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Tie her to the horses tail.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We know how to use her,
But not your way, for all your state.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Make haste there:
And get you in, and look to the house . If you stir out, Damsel,
Or set afoot any new motion this way,
When I come home, (which shall be suddenly)
You know my mind: if you do play the rascal,
I have my eyes and ears in sundry places,
If ye do prance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I shall do that, that is fit, sir:
And fit to cross your fooleries; I will fail else.
And so I will to my chamber.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: To your prayers,
And leave your stubborn tricks: She is not far yet,
She cannot be; and we dividing suddenly.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Keep her from thy hands, I beseech.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Our horses;
Come cheerfully. I will teach her to run gadding.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: Captain,you are not merry.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: We get nothing,
We have no sport; whoring, and drinking spoils us,
We keep no guards.
There come no passengers,
Merchants, nor Gentlemen, nor whosoever,
But we have Tribute.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And whilst we spend that idly,
We let those pass that carry the best purchase.
I will have all searched and; brought in; Rogues,and Beggars,
Have got the trick now to become Bank masters.
I will have none scape: only my friends, and neighbours,
That may deliver to the King my innocence;
Those I would have regarded; it is policy.
But otherwise nor gravities, nor shadows,
Appear they how they will, that may have purses,
For they shall pay.
Ye speak now like a Captain.
And if we spare, flea us, and coin our Cassocks;
Will ye look blithe?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You hear no preparation
The King intends against us yet?
Not a word sir.
Good man, he is troubled with matter of more moment,
Hummings of higher nature vex his brains, sir;
Do not we fee his garrisons?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Who are out now?
Good fellows sir, that if there be any purchase stirring
Will strike it dead; and Lads Loper
That know their quarters, as they know their knapsacks;
And will not off.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Where is the boy ye brought me?
A pretty lad, and of a quick capacity,
And bred up neatly.
He is within at meat, sir,
The knave is hungry: yet he seasons all
He eats or drinks with many tears and sighings,
The saddest appetite I ever looked on;
The boy is young, it is fear and want of company
He knows and loves: use him not rough, nor harshly,
He will be quickly bold; I will entertain him:
I want a pretty Boy to wait upon me,
And when I am sad or sleepy, to prate to me;
Besides there is something in his face, I like well.
And still the more I look, more like; let him want nothing,
And use him gently, all.
Here is a small Box, sir,
We took about him, which he grieved to part with,
May be some wealth.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Alas, some little money
The poor knave carried to defray his lodgings,
I will give it him again ,and add unto it.
It were sin to open such a petty purchase.

body.stage: Enter Loper and Jaques, with Pedro.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How now, who is this? what have you brought me Soldiers?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We know not well what: a strange staving fellow,
Sullen enough I am sure.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Where took ye him?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Upon the skirt of the wood, viewing, and gaping,
And sometime standing still, as if he had meant
To view the best accesses to our quarters;
Money he has enough: and when we threatened him,
He smiled, and yielded; but not one word uttered.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: His habit says he is holy: if his heart
Keep that proportion too, it is best ye free him,
We keep his Wallet here: I am sure it is heavy.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Pilgrim: come hither sir; Are you a Pilgrim?
A piece of pretty holiness: do you shrink sir?
A smug young Saint. What Country were you born in?
Ye have a Spanish face: In a dumb Province?
And had your mother too this excellent virtue?
no tongue do you say? sure she was a matchless woman;
What a fine family is this man sprung from
Certain he was begotten in a calm,
When all was hushed: the Midwife was dumb Midnight;
Are ye sealed up? or do you scorn to answer?
Ye are in my hands, and I have medicines for ye
Can make ye speak: pull off his Bonnet, Soldiers;
Ye have a speaking face.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am sure a handsome:
This Pilgrim cannot want She Saints to pray to.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Stand nearer: ha?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Come, do your worst; I am ready.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Is your tongue found? go off, and let me talk with him;
And keep your watches round.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are ready Captain.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: So: now what are ye?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Am I?
My habit shows me what I am.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thy heart
A desperate fool, and so thy fate shall tell thee;
What devil brought thee hither? for I know thee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I know thou dost: and since it is my fortune
To light into thy fingers; I must think too
The most malicious of all devils brought me,
Yet some men say thou art Noble.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Not to thee,
That were a benefit to mock the giver:
Thy father hates my friends, and family,
And thou hast been the heir of all this malice.
Can two such storms meet then, and part with kissing?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You have the mightier hand.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: And so I will use it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I cannot hinder ye: less can I beg
Submissive at his knees that knows not honour;
That bears the stamp of man, and not his nature;
Ye may do what ye please.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I will do all.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And when you have done all, which is my poor ruin,
(For farther your base malice cannot venture)
Dishonours self will cry you out a coward.
Hadst thou been brave, and noble and an Enemy,
Thou wouldst have sought me whilst I carried Arms,
Whilst my good Sword was my profession,
And then have cried out Pedro, I defy thee;
Then stuck Alphonso's quarrel on the point,
The mercenary anger thou servest under
To get his daughter. Then thou shouldest have braved me,
And armed with all thy families hate upon me,
Done something worthy feat: Now poor and basely
Thou settest Toils to betray me; and like the Peasant,
That dares not meet the Lion in the face,
Diggest crafty pit falls: Thou shamest the Spanish honour:
Thou hast neither point of man, nor conscience in thee.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sir, sir,you are brave; ye plead now in a Sanctuary;
You think your Pilgrims bulwark can defend ye:
You will not find it so.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I look not for it.
The more unhallowed soul hast thou to offer it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: When you were bravest, sir, and your Sword sharpest,
I durst affront ye: when the Court Sun gilded ye,
And every cry was the young hopeful Pedro
Alonsos sprightly son; then durst I meet ye,
When you were Master of this fame, and fashion,
And all your glories in the full Meridian,
The Kings proof favour buckled on your body;
Had we then come to competition,
Which I have often sought.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And I desired too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You should have seen this Sword, how ere you sleight it,
And felt it too; sharper than sorrow felt it,
In execution quicker than thy scorns;
Thou shouldest have seen all this, and shrunk to see it.
Then like a Gentleman I would have used thee,
And given thee the fair fortune of thy being,
Then with a Soldiers Arm I had honoured thee;
But since thou stealest upon me like a Spy,
And thief like thinkst that holy case shall carry thee
Through all my purposes, and so betray me,
Base as you act, thy end be, and I forget thee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What poor evasions thou buildest on, to abuse me?
The goodness of a man never taught these principles.
I come a Spy? durst any Noble spirit
Put on this habit,to become a Traitor?
Even in an Enemy show me this antipathy
Where there is Christian faith, and this not reverenced:
I come a Spy? no no, Roderigo
A hater of thy person, a maligner?
So far from that, I brought no malice with me,
But rather when I meet thee, tears to soften thee;
When I put on this habit, I put off
All fires, all angers, all those starts of youth
That clapped too rank a bias to my being,
And drew me from the right mark all should aim at;
In stead of stubborn steel, I put on prayers;
For rash and hasty heats, a sweet repentance:
Long weary steps, and vows,for my vain glories.
O Roderigo

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: If thy tongue could save thee,
Prating be thy bail, thou hast a rare benefit.
Soldiers, come out, and bring a halter with ye;
I will forgive your holy habit sir, but I will hang you.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: Wherefore this halter Captain?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: For this traitor.
Go, put it on him, and then tie him up:
Do you want a Band sir? this is a course wearing,
It will sit but scurvily upon this collar;
But patience is as good as a French Pickadell.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: What is his fault, Captain?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: It is my will he perish,
And that is his fault.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A Captain of good government.
Come Soldiers, come, ye are roughly bred, and bloody,
Show your obedience, and the joy ye take
In executing impious commands;
Ye have a Captain seals your liberal pardons,
Be no more Christians, put religion by,
It will make ye cowards: feel no tenderness,
Nor let a thing called conscience trouble ye;
Alas, it will breed delay. Bear no respect
To what I seem: were I a Saint indeed,
Why should that stagger ye? you know not holiness:
To be excellent in evil, is your goodness;
And be so, it will become ye: have no hearts,
For fear you should repent: that will be dangerous:
For if there be a knocking there, a pricking,
And that pulse beat back to your considerations,
How ye have laid a stiff hand on Religion

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Truss him I say.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And violated faith,

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: hear him not prate.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Why,what a thing will this be?
What strange confusion then will breed among ye?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Will none of ye obey?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What devils vex ye?
The fears ye live in and the hourly dangers
Will be delights to these: those have their ends,
But these outlive all time, and all repentance:
And if it creep into your conscience once,
Be sure ye lock that close.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why stand ye gazing?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Farewell sleep, peace, all that are human comforts,
Better ye had been Trees, or Stones, and happier;
For those die here, and seek no further being,
Nor hopes, nor punishments.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Rots take ye Rascals.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: What would you have us do?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Dispatch the prater.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And have religious blood hang on our consciences?
We are bad enough already: sins enough
To make our graves even loath us.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: no man love me?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Although I be a thief, I am no hangman;
They are two men's trades, and let another execute.
Lay violent hands on holy things?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Base Cowards,
Put to your powers, ye Rascals, I command ye.
Holy, or unholy, if I say it,
I will have it done.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: If I do it, let me starve for it.
Or I.
Or I: we will obey things handsome,
And bad enough, and over do obedience:
But to be made such instruments of mischief.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I have done as many villainies as another,
And with as little reluctation,
Let me come clear of these, and wipe that score off.
Put me upon a felt and known perdition?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Have ye conspired, ye slaves?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How vildly this shows,
In one that would command another's temper,
And bear no bound in his own?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Am I thus jaded?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is it my life thou longest for Roderigo
And can no sacrifice appease thy malice,
But my blood spilt? do it thyself ,dispatch it;
And as thou takest the whole revenge unto thee,
Take the whole sin upon thee; and be mighty,
Mighty in evil, as thou art in anger:
And let not these poor wretches howl for thy sake.
Those things that in thine own glass seem most monstrous,
Wouldst thou abuse their weak sights with, for amiable?
Is it, thou thinkst to fear me with thy terrors,
And into weak condition draw my virtue?
If I were now to learn to die I would sue to thee:
Or did I fear death, then I would make thee glorious.
But knowing what, and how far I can suffer;
And all my whole life being but deaths preface,
My sleep but at next door.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Are ye so valiant?
I will make ye feel: I will make ye know, and feel too;
And Rascals, you shall tremble. Keep him here,
And keep him safe too: if he scape your guards

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Fear not, I will not.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: As I live, ye die for it;
I will not be thus baffled.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: What a devil have ye done, Pilgrim? or what mischief
Have you conspired, that he should rage and rave thus?
Have you killed his father, or his mother? or strangled any of his kindred?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Has he no sisters? have you not been bouncing
About their belly pieces?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Why should that be dangerous
Or any way deserve death? is it not natural?
Bar us the Christian liberty of women,
And build us up with brick, take away our free stone.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: Because thou art holier than he, upon my conscience
He does not envy thee: that is not his quarrel;
For, look you, that might be copounded without prayers.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nor that thou seemest an honester man: for here
We have no trading with such Tinsell stuff;
To be an excellent thief, is all we aim at.
Wilt thou take a spit and stride, and see if thou canst outrun us?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I scorn to shift his fury, keep your obedience;
For though your government admit no president,
Keep yourselves careful in it.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Thou will be hanged then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I cannot die with fewer faults upon me.

sp.speaker: 2 Outl.
sp.l: It is ten to one he will shoot him: for the devil is in him
If he hang him himself.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He has too proud a nature:
He will compel someone .

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I am confident.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And so are all I think.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Be not molested,
If I must die, let it not trouble you;
It stirs not me: It is the end I was born for.
Only this honest office I desire ye,
(If there be courtesy in men of your breed)
To see me buried; not to let his fury
Expose my body to the open violence
Of beasts, and fowls: so far I urge humanity.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: He shall not deny us that: we will see ye under ground
And give ye a volley of as good cups of Sack,
For that is our Discipline.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He comes again,
As high in rage as ever; the boy with him.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: Will he compel the child?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He is bent to do it,
And must have somebody .

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: If thou lovest me do it:
Love me, or love me not, I say thou shalt do it:
Stare not, nor stagger, sirrah; if ye deny me,
Do you see this Rogue?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: What would ye have me do sir?
Heavens goodness bless me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Do? why hang a Rascal,
That would hang me.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I am a boy, and weak, sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thou art strong enough to tie him to a Bough,
And turn him off: come, thou shalt be my Jewel,
And I will allow thee horse, and all thy pleasures,
And twenty gallant things: I will teach thee arms too;
Make thee mine heir.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Let me inherit death first.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Make me not angry, sirra.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Which is the man, sir?
I will pluck up the best heart I can yet.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Fear not,
It is my will: That in the Pilgrims coat there,
That devil in the Saints skin.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Guard me goodness.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Dispatch him presently.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I wait your worst, sir.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: will the boy do it? is the rogue so confident?
So young,so deep in blood?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He shakes, and trembles.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Dost thou seek more coals still to sear thy conscience,
Work sacred innocence, to be a devil?
Do it thyself for shame, thou best becomest it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Sirra , I scorn my finger should be filled with thee;
And yet I will have it done: this child shall strangle thee;
A crying Girl, if she were here should master thee.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: How should I save him? how myself from violence?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Leave your tongue valour, and; dispatch your hate, sir;
The patience of my death, shall more torment thee,
(Thou painted honour, thou base man made backward)
Than all my life has feared thee.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Gag him, sirra.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: The Boy looks cheerfully now: sure he will do it.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: He will mall him else.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Are ye prepared to die, sir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes boy, and ready; prithee to thy business.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Why are ye then so angry? so perplexed, sir?
Patience wins Heaven, and not the heat of passion.
Why do you rail?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The boy is a pretty Priest.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I thank ye gentle child, you teach me truly.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You seem to fear too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Thou seest more, than I feel,boy.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You tremble sure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: no sure boy, it is thy tenderness:
Prithee make haste, and let that gulf be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Are ye so willing to go to it?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Most willing:
I would not borrow from his courtesy
One hour of life, to gain an age of glory.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And is your reckoning straight sir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As straight as truth, boy:
I cannot go more joyfully to a wedding.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Then to your prayers: I will dispatch ye presently.
Now guide my tongue, thou blessedness.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: A good boy.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: But hark ye sir, one word;and pray ye resolve me.
Let me speak privately.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What wouldst thou have child?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Shall this man die?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why dost thou make that question?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Pray ye be not angry: if he must, I will do it.
But must he now?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What else? who dare reprieve him?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Pray ye think again; and as your injuries
Are great, and full, you suffer from this fellow,
Do not ye purpose so to suit your vengeance?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I do, and must.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You cannot if he die now.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Cannot?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: no, cannot: be not vexed, you will find it.
I have considered, and I know it certain,
Ye suffer below him: lose all your angers.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why my best boy?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I love, and tender ye,
I would not tell ye else. Is that revenge,
To sleight your cause, and Saint your enemy,
Clap the Doves wings of downy peace unto him,
And let him soar to Heaven, whilst you are sighing?
Is this revenge?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I would have him die.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Prepared thus?
The blessing of a father never reached it:
His contemplation now scorns ye, contemns ye,
And all the tortures ye can use. Let him die thus;
And these that know and love revenge will laugh at ye:
Here lies the honour of a well bred anger,
To make his enemy shake and tremble under him;
Doubt: nay, almost despair,and then confound him.
This man ye rock asleep, and all your rages
Are Requiems to his parting soul, mere Anthems.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Indeed he is strongly built.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You cannot shake him;
And the more weight ye put on his foundation,
Now as he stands, ye fix him still the stronger;
If ye love him, honour him, would heap upon him
Friendships and benefits beyond example,
Hope him a Star in Heaven, and there would stick him,
Now take his life.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I had rather take mine own,Boy.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I will ease him presently.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Stay, be not hasty.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Bless my tongue still.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: What has the boy done to him?
How dull, and still he looks?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You are a wise man.
And long have buckled with the worlds extremities,
A valiant man, and no doubt know both fortunes,
And would ye work your Master piece thus madly,
Take the bare name of honour, that will pity ye
When the world knows ye have preyed on a poor Pilgrim?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The Boy has staggered me: what wouldst thou have me?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Have ye? do you not feel Sir? does it not stir ye?
Do you ask a child? I would have ye do most bravely,
Because I most affect ye: like yourself Sir,
Scorn him, and let him go; seem to contemn him,
And now ye have made him shake, seal him his pardon,
When he appears a subject fit for Anger,
And fit for you, his pious Armour off,
His hopes no higher than your sword may reach at
Then strike, and then ye know revenge; then take it.
I hope I have turned his mind.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Let the fool go there,
I scorn to let loose so base an anger
May light on thee: See me no more,but quit me;
And when we meet again.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I will thank ye Captain.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Why this was like yourself: but which way goes he?
Shall we never happy meet?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I am drowsy; Boy,
Go with me, and discourse: I like thy company
O Child I love thy Tongue.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I shall wait on ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The Boy has done it : a Plaguey witty Rascal.
And I shall love him terribly.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: It was he most certain,
For if ye mark, how earnest he was with him,
And how he laboured him.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A cunning villain,
But a good Rogue; This Boy will make us all honest.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: I scarce believe that: but I like the Boy well
Come,let us to Supper; then upon our watches.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This Pilgrim scaped a joyful one.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Let us Drink round,
To the Boys health, and then about our business.

body.stage: Enter Roderigo, Iaques, Loper, and three Out Lawes.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: None of you know her?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Alas Sir, we never saw her:
Nor ever heard of her, but from your report.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: no happy eye?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I do not think it is she, Sir,
Methinks a woman dares not.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thou speakest poorly,
What dares not woman, when she is provoked?
Or what seems dangerous to Love, or fury?
That it is she, this has confirmed me certain,
These Jewels here, a part of which I sent her,
And though unwilling, yet her Father wrought her
To take, and wear.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A wench, and we not know it?
And among us? where were our understandings?
I could have guessed unhappily: have had some feeling
In such a matter: Here are as pretty fellows,
At the discovery of such a Jigambob:
A handsome wench too? sure we have lost our faculties,
We have no motions: what should she do here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: That is it that troubles me: O that base Rascal
There lies the misery: how cunningly she quit him,
And how she urged? had ye been constant to me,
I never had suffered this.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: Ye might have hanged him:
And would he had been hanged; that is all we care for it:
So our hands had not done it .

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: She is gone again too,
And what care have ye for that? gone, and contemned me;
Mastered my will, and power, and now laughs at me.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The devil that brought her hither, Sir I think
Has carried her back again invisible,
For we never knew, nor heard of her departure.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: no living thing came this night through our watches
She went with you:

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Was by me till I slept,
But when I waked, and called: O my dull pate here,
If I had opened this when it was given me,
This Roguey Box.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: We could but give it ye.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Pilgrim? a Pox O Pilgrims there the game goes,
There is all my fortune fled; I know it, I feel it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Bring me unto thy Captain: where is thy Captain?
I am foundered, melted, some fairy thing or other
Has led me dancing; the devil has haunted me
In the likeness of a voice: give me thy Captain.

sp.speaker: 2 Outl.
sp.l: He is here Sir, there he stands.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How dost thou Captain?
I have been fooled and jaded, made a dog bolt.
My daughter is run away: I have been haunted too,
I have lost my horse; I am hungry, and; out of my wits also.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Come in; I will tell you what I know: strange things
And take your ease; I will follow her recovery,
These shall be yours the whilst, and do ye service.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let me have drink enough: I am almost choked too.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You shall have anything ; what think you now, Soldiers?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I think a woman, is a woman that is anything.
The next we take, we will search a little nearer,
We will not be boyed again with a pair of breeches.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He is gone in here: This is quarter, Roderigo's
And I will be with him soon : I will startle him,
A little better than I have done: All this long night
I have led him out of the way, to try his patience,
And made him swear, and curse; and pray,and swear again ,
And cry for anger; I made him leave his horse too,
Where he can never find him more; whistled to him,
And then he would run through thick and; thin,to reach me,
And down in this ditch; up again,and shake him
And swear some certain blessings; then into that bush
Pop goes his pate, and all his face is combed over,
And I sit laughing: a hundred tricks, I have served him:
And I will double them, before I leave him;
I will teach his anger to dispute with women,
But all this time, I cannot meet my Mistress,
I cannot come to comfort her; that grieves me,
For sure she is much afflicted: till I do,
I will haunt thy Ghost Alphonso; I will keep thee waking,
Yes, I must get a Drum: I am villainous weary,
And yet I will trot about these villages
Till I have got my will, and then have at ye.
I will make your anger drop out at your elbows ere I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It is strange, in all the circuit we have ridden,
We cannot cross her: no way light upon her:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I do not think she is gone thus far, or this way,
For certain if she had, we should have reached her
Made some discovery: heard some news; we have seen nothing.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nor pass by anybody that could promise anything.
She is certainly disguised, her modesty
Durst never venture else.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Let her take any shape,
And let me see it once, I can distinguish it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So should I think too: has not her father found her?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: no, I will be hanged then; he has no patience
Unless she light in his teeth, to look about him.
He guesses now, and chafes and frets like Tinsell.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Let him go on, he cannot live without it.
But keep her from him, heaven: where are we Curio

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: In a wood I think, hang me if I know else.
And yet I have ridden all these Coasts, at all hours,
And had and aim.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I would we had a guide,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: And if I be not much awry Seberto
Not far off should be quarter, Rodorigo's
For in this Fastness if I be not cozened,
He and his Outlaws live.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This is the place then

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We appointed him to meet in.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Yes, I think so:

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Would we could meet some living thing: what is that there?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A Boy, I think, stay; why may not he direct us.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I am hungry, and I am weary, and I cannot find him.
Keep my wits heaven, I feel them wavering,
O God my head.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Boy, dost thou hear,thou stripling?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Now they will tear me, torture me, now Roderigo
Will hang him without mercy; ha:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Come hither.
A very pretty Boy: what place is this, child?
And whether dost thou travel? how he stares
Some stubborn Master has abused the Boy,
And beaten him: how he complains whether goest thou?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I go to Sir, to my sick Mother, Segonia
I have been taken here by drunken thieves,
And O my bones; I have been beaten Sir.
Misused and; robbed: extremely beaten Gentlemen,
O God, my side

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What beasts would use a Boy thus?
Look up, and be of good cheer:

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O, I cannot.
My back, my back, my back.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: What thieves?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I know not.
But they call the Captain Roderigo

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Look ye,
I know we were there abouts;

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Dost thou want anything ?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Nothing but ease, but ease, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: There is some money,
And get thee to thy Mother.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I thank ye Gentlemen:

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This was extremely foul, to vex a Child thus.
Come, let us along, we cannot lose our way now.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Though ye are honest men, I fear your fingers,
And glad I am got off; O how I tremble
Send me but once within his arms dear Fortune,
And then come all the world: what shall I do now?
It is almost night again, and where to lodge me,

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Or get me meat, or anything , I know not.
These willed woods, and the fancies I have in me,
Will run me mad.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Boy, Boy:

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: More set to take me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Dost thou hear Boy; thou pointer.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: It is a Boy too,
A Lackey Boy: I need not fear his fierceness.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Canst thou beat a Drum?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: A Drum?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This thing, a drum here.
Didst thou never see a Drum: Canst thou make this grumble?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Iulettas face, and tongue; Is she run mad too?
Here may be double craft: I have no skill in it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I will give thee a Royal but to go along with me.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I care not for thy Royal, I have other business,
Drum to thyself, and dance to it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sirra, sirra .
Thou scurvy Sitha; thou snotty nosed scab, dost thou hear me?
If I lay down my Drum.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Here comes more Company,
I fear a plot, heaven send me fairly from it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Basto; who is here?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Captain, do you need me Father?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: no not a foot: give me the gown: the sword now.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This is the devil thief, and if he take me,
Woe be to my Galley gaskins.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Certain Sir,
She will take her patches off , and change her habit.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Let her do what she please: no,no Alinda
You cannot cozen me again in a Boys figure,
Nor hide the beauty of that face in patches,
But I shall know it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A Boy his face in patches?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nor shall your tongue again bewitch mine Anger,
If she be found in the woods, send me word presently,
And I will return; she cannot be far gone yet,
If she be not, expect me, when ye see me,
Use all your service to my friend Alphonso
And have a care to your business: farewell,
no more, farewell.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am heartily glad thou art gone yet.
This Boy in patches, was the Boy came by me,
The very same, how hastily it shifted?
What a mope eyed ass was I, I could not know her,
This must be she, this is she, now I remember her,
How loath she was to talk too, how she feared me?
I could now piss mine eyes out for mere anger:
I will follow her, but who shall vex her father then?
One flirt at him, and then I am for the voyage,
If I can cross the Captain too: Come Tabor.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Are they all set?

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: All, and each quarter quiet.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Is the old man asleep?

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: An hour ago Sir.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: We must be very careful in his absence,
And very watchful.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: It concerns us nearly,
He will not be long from us.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: no, he cannot,

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: A little heat of love, which he must wander out.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: And then again: hark.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: It is not the wind sure:
That is still and calm; no noise, nor flux of waters.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I hear a Drum, I think.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: That that;
It beats again now.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Now it comes nearer: sure we are surprised,sir;
Some from the Kings command: we are lost, we are dead all.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: Hark, hark, a charge now: my Captain has betrayed us.
And left us to this ruin, run away from us.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Another beats on that side.

sp.speaker: 2 Outl.
sp.l: Fly, fly, Jaques
We are taken in a toil; snapped in a pitfall;
Methinks I feel a Sword already shave me.

sp.speaker: 3 Outl.
sp.l: A thousand horse and foot, a thousand pioneers,
If we get underground, to fetch us out again ;
And every one an Axe to cut the woods down.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This is the dismalest night

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Where is my nag now?
And what make I here to be hanged? What devil
brought me into this danger? Is there never a hole?
That I may creep in deep enough,and die quickly?
Never an old ditch to choke in? I shall be taken
For their Commander now, their General,
And have a commanding Gallows set up for me
As high as a May pole; and nasty Songs made on me,
Be printed with a Pint pot and a dagger.
They are all killed by this time: Can I pray?
Let me see that first: I have too much fear to be faithful.
Where is all my State now? I must go hunt for daughters;
Daughters, and damsels of the Lake, damned daughters.
A hundred Crowns for a good tod of Hey,
Or a fine hollow Tree, that would contain me;
I hear them coming : I feel the noose about me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why do you fear, and fly? here are no Soldiers;
None from the King to vex ye.

sp.speaker: 1 Outl.
sp.l: The Drum, the Drum,sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I never saw such Pigeon hearted people:
What Drum? what danger? who is that that shakes behind there:
Mercy upon me sir, why are ye feared thus?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Are we all killed, no mercy to be hoped for?
Am I not shot do you think?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You are strangely frighted,
Shot with a fiddle stick: who is here to shoot ye?
A Drum we saw indeed, a boy was beating it,
And hunting Squirrels by Moon light.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nothing else,sir?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Not anything : no other person stirring.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: O that I had that boy: this is that Devil,
That fairy rogue, that haunted me last night;
He has sleeves like Dragons wings.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A little Foot boy.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Come, let us go in,and let me get my clothes on;
If ere I stay here more to be thus martyred
Did ye not meet the wench?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: no sure, we met her not.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: She has been here in boys apparel, Gentlemen,
A gallant thing, and famous for a Gentlewoman,
And all her face patched over for discovery:
A pilgrim too, and thereby hangs a circumstance,
That she hath played her master prize, a rare one.
I came too short.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Such a young boy we met sir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: In a gray hat.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: The same: his face all patched too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: It was she, a rot run with her; she: that rank she;
Walk in, I will tell ye all: and then we will part again,
But get some store of Wine: this fright sits here yet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What a fright I have put them in; what a brave hurry.
If this do bolt him, I will be with him again
With a new part, was never played; I will fork him.
As he hunts her, so I will hunt him: I will claw him.
Now will I see if I can cross her footing:
Yet still I will watch his water, he shall pay for it;
And when he thinks most malice, and means worse,
I will make him know the Mare is the better Horse.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Ye are a stranger sir, and for humanity,
Being come within our walls, I would show you something.
Ye have seen the Castle?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes sir, it is a strong one,
And well maintained.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why are you still thus sad, sir?
How do ye like the walks?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They are very pleasant;
Your Town stands cool and sweet.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But that I would not
Affect you with more sadness, I could show ye
A place worth view.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Shows seldom alter me sir;
Pray ye speak it, and then show it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It is a house here
Where people of all sorts, that have been visited
With lunacies and follies wait their cures,
There is fancies of a thousand stamps and fashions,
Like flies in several shapes buzz round about ye,
And twice as many gestures; some of pity,
That it would make ye melt to see their passions:
And some as light again, that would content ye.
But I see sir, your temper is too modest,
Too much inclined to contemplation,
To meet with these?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You could not please me better;
And I beseech you sir, do me the honour
To let me wait upon ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Since ye are willing,
To me it shall be a pleasure to conduct ye.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I never had such a mind yet to see misery.

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: Carry mad some meat, she roars like Thunder; Besse
And tie the Parson short, the Moon is in the full,
He has a thousand Pigs in his brains: Who looks to the Prentice?
Keep him from women, he thinks he has lost his Mistress,
And talk of no silk stuffs, it will run him horn mad.

sp.speaker: 2 Keep.
sp.l: The Justice keeps such a stir yonder with his Charges,
And such a coil with warrants,

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: Take away his Statutes;
The devil has possessed him in the likeness
Of penal Laws: keep him from Aquavit,
For if that spirit creep into his corum,
He will commit us all: how is it with the Scholar?

sp.speaker: 2 Keep.
sp.l: For anything I see, he is in his right wits.

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: Thou art an ass; in his right wits, goodman coxcomb?
As though any man durst be in his right wits, and be here.
It is as much as we dare be that keep them .

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Give me some drink.

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: O, there is the English man.

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Fill me a thousand pots, and froth them, froth them.
Down on your knees, ye rogues, and pledge me roundly;
One,two,three,and four; we shall be all merry within this hour.
To the great Turk.

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: Peace, peace, thou Heathen drunkard;
These English are so Malt mad,there is no meddling with them;
When they have a fruitful year of Barley there,
All the whole Island is thus.

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: A Snuff, a snuff, a snuff.
A lewd notorious snuff: give it him again, boy.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: God ye good even, Goffer.

sp.speaker: 2 Keep.
sp.l: Who let the Fool loose?

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: If any of the mad men take her, she is peppered,
They will bounce her loins.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Will ye walk into the cole house?

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: She is as lecherous too as a she ferret.

sp.speaker: 2 Keep.
sp.l: Who a vengeance looks to her? go in Kate
I will give thee a fine Apple.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Will ye buss me?
And tickle me, and make me laugh?

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: I will whip ye.

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Fool, fool, come up to me fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Are ye peeping?

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: I will get thee with five fools.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: O fine, O dainty.

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: And thou shalt lie in in a horse cloth, like a Lady

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: And shall I have a Coach?

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Drawn with four Turkeys,
And they shall tread thee too.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: We shall have eggs then;
And shall I sit upon them?

sp.speaker: Engl.
sp.l: Aye, aye , and they shall be all addle,
And make an admirable Tanzey for the devil.
Come, come away, I am taken with thy love fool,
And will mightily be labour thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: How the fool bridles? how she twitters at him?
These Englishmen would stagger a wise woman.
If we should suffer her to have her will now,
We should have all the women in Spain as mad as she here,

sp.speaker: 2 Keep.
sp.l: They would strive who should be most fool: away with her.

body.stage: Enter Master, three Gentlemen, a mad Scholler, and Pedro.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Pray ye stay a little: let us hear him sing, he has a fine breast.

sp.speaker: 1 Keep.
sp.l: Here comes my Master; to the spit ye whore,
And stir no more abroad, but tend your business;
Your shall have no more sops in the pan else, nor no porridge:
Besides, I will whip your breech.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: I will go in presently.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will assure ye sir, the Cardinal is angry with ye
For keeping this young man.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I am heartily sorry.
If ye allow him sound, pray ye take him with ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This is the place, and now observe their humours:

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: We can find nothing in him light, nor tainted;
no startings, nor no rubs, in all his answers,
In all his Letters nothing but discretion,
Learning, and handsome style.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Be not deceived sir,
Mark but his look.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: His grief, and his imprisonment
May stamp that there.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Pray talk with him again then.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: That will be needless, we have tried him long enough,
And if he had a taint we should have met with it.
Yet to discharge your care

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A sober youth:
Pity so heavy a cross should light upon him.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: You find no sickness?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: None sir, I thank Heaven,
Nor nothing that diverts my understanding.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Do you sleep a nights?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: As sound, and sweet, as any man:

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Have ye no fearful dreams?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Sometimes, as all have
That go to bed with raw and windy stomachs;
Else, I am all one piece.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Is there no unkindness
You have conceived from any friend or parent?
Or scorn from what ye loved?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: no, truly sir:
I never yet was master of a faith
So poor,and weak, to doubt my friend or kindred,
And what love is, unless it lie in learning
I think I am ignorant.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This man is perfect,
A civiler discourser I never talked with.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: You will find it otherwise.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I must tell ye true sir,
I think ye keep him here to teach him madness.
Here is his discharge from my Lord Cardinal;
And come sir,go with us.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: I am bound unto ye,
And farewell Master.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Farewell Stephano
Alas poor man.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What flaws,and whirls of weather,
Or rather storms have been aloft these three days;
How dark, and hot, and full of mutiny
And still grows louder.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: It has been stubborn weather.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Strange work at Sea, I fear me there is old tumbling.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Bless my old uncles Bark, I have a venture.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: And I more than I would wish to lose.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Do you fear?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Ha! how he looks?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Nay, mark him better Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Mercy upon me: how his eyes are altered?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Now tell me how ye like him: whether now
He be that perfect man ye credited?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Does the Sea stagger ye?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Now ye have hit the nick.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Do ye fear the billows?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What ails him? who has stirred him?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Be not shaken,
Nor let the singing of the storm shoot through ye,
Let it blow on, blow on: let the clouds wrestle,
And let the vapours of the earth turn mutinous,
The Sea in hideous mountains rise and tumble
Upon a Dolphins back,I will make all tremble,
For I am Neptune

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Now what think ye of him?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Alas poor man.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Your Bark shall plough through all,
And not a Surge so saucy to disturb her.
I will see her safe, my power shall sail before her.
Down ye angry waters all,
Ye loud whistling whirlwinds fall;
Down ye proud Waves, ye storms cease;
I command ye, be at peace.
Fright not with your churlish Notes,
Nor bruise the Keel of Bark, that floats:
no devouring Fish come nigh,
Nor Monster in my Empery,
Once show his head,or terror bring;
But let the weary Sailor sing:
Amphitrite with white arms
Strike my Lute,I will sing Charms.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: He must have Music now: I must observe him.
His fit will grow to full else.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I must pity him.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Now he will in himself most quietly,
And clean forget all, as he had done nothing.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We are sorry,sir: and we have seen a wonder;
From this hour we will believe, and so we will leave ye.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This was a strange fit.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Did ye mark him sir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He might have cozened me with his behaviour.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Many have sworn him right, and I have thought so:
Yet on a sudden, from some word,or other,
When no man could expect a fit, he has flown out:
I dare not give him will.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Pray Heaven recover him.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Must I come in too?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: no, my pretty Lad;
Keep in thy chamber Boy: shalt have thy supper.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I pray ye what is he sir?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: A strange boy, that last night
Was found in the Town, a little crazed, distracted,
And so sent hither.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How the pretty knave looks,
And plays, and peeps upon me sure such eyes
I have seen, and loved: what fair hands? certainly

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Good sir, you will make him worse.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I pray believe not.
Alas, why should I hurt him? how he smiles?
The very shape, and sweetness of Alinda
Let me look once again: were it in such clothes
As when I saw her last; this must be she.
How tenderly it strokes me?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Pray ye be mild sir;
I must attend elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Pray ye be secure sir,
What would ye say? how my heart beats and trembles?
He holds me hard by the hand ; O my life, her flesh too
I know not what to think: her tears, her true ones;
Pure orient tears: Hark,do you know me little one?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O Pedro Pedro

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O my soul

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What fit is this?
The Pilgrims off the hooks too.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Let me hold thee,
And now come all the world, and all that hate me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Be wise, and not discovered: O how I love ye
How do ye now?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I have been miserable;
But your most virtuous eyes have cured me, Pedro
Pray ye think it no immodesty, I kiss ye,
My head is willed still.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Be not so full of passion,
Nor do not hang so greedily upon me;
It will be ill taken.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Are ye weary of me?
I will hang here eternally,kiss ever,
And weep away for joy.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I told ye sir,
What ye would do: for shame do not afflict him;
You have drawn his fit upon him fearfully:
Either depart, and presently; I will force ye else.
Who waits within?

body.stage: Enter two Keepers to fetch 'em off.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Alas good sir.
This is the way never to hope recovery.
Stay but one minute more, I will complain to the Governor.
Bring in the boy: do you see how he swells, and tears himself?
Is this your cure? Be gone; if the boy miscarry
Let me never find you more, for I will so hamper ye

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You were too blame: too rash.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Farewell forever .

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are now within a mile of the Town sir: if my business
Would give me leave, I would turn and wait upon ye;
But for such Gentlemen as you enquire of,
Certain, I saw none such: But for the boy ye spoke of,
I will not say it is he, but such a one;
Just of that height.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: In such clothes?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I much mistake else,
Was sent in the other night, a little muddies,
And where such people wait their cures.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I understand ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: There you may quickly know.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I thank ye sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So do I too : and if there be such a place,
I ask no more; but you shall hear more of me.
She may be there, and you may play the tyrant;
I will see what I can do: I am almost foundered
In following him; and yet I will never leave him,
I will crawl of all four first; my cause is meritorious,
And come what can come.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: All you have told me is certain;
Complexion,and all else.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: It may be she then;
And I will so fumble her: Is she grown mad now?
Is her blood set so high? I will have her madded,
I will have her wormed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mark but the end, old Master,
If thou beest not sick of the Bots within these five hours,
And kickest and roarest; I will make ye fart fire, Seignior,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here is one of the house, a fool, an idiot sir;
May be she is going home; she will be a guide to ye:
And so I kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O now I am lost, lost, lost, Lord,how I tremble
My father, armed in all his hates and angers;
This is more misery than I have scaped yet.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Fool, fool.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: He knows me not; will ye give me two pence?
And gaffer, here is a Crow flower, and a Daisy;
I have some pie in my pocket too.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: This is an arrant fool,
An ignorant thing.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Believe so, and I am happy.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Dost thou dwell in Sigonia, fool?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: no no, I dwell in Heaven.
And I have a fine little house, made of Marmalade.
And I am a lone woman, and I spin for Saint Peter
I have a hundred little children, and they sing Psalms with me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: It is pity this pretty thing should want understanding.
But why do I stand talking with a coxcomb?
If I do find her, if I light upon her,
I will say no more. Is this the way to the Town ,fool?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You must go over the top of that high steeple, Gaffer.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: A plague on your fools face.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: no, take her counsel.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And then you shall come to a River twenty mile over,
And twenty mile and; ten: and then you must pray, Gaffer;
And still you must pray, and pray.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Pray Heaven deliver me
From such an ass, as thou art.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Amen, sweet Gaffer.
And fling a sop of Sugar cake into it;
And then you must leap in naked.

sp.speaker: Jul.
